item.title: Nately Scures Probate Material 1681-1700
item.description:
Five wills and seven inventories survive for this period including four husbandmen and one yeoman.  SOme of the testators lived in Holt and Andwell, the detached parts of the parish.

Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. 

Links to the transcriptions are below.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

  • Edward Bayly, 1683 (Will & Inventory)
  • Edward Shrimpton, 1683 (Inventory)
  • Philip Gillam, 1684 (Inventory)
  • Grace Nutby, widow, 1684 (Will & Inventory)
  • Anne South, 1686 (Inventory)
  • Richard King, husbandman, 1691 (Will)
  • William Wigg, husbandman, 1691 (Inventory)
  • John King, husbandman, 1694 (Will)
  • James Baldchild/Balchild, yeoman, 1695 (Will & Inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Nately Scures Probate Material 1661-1680
item.description:
Two wills and three inventories survive for this period, one of which is the rector John Palmer, who was resident in the parish for 10 years and has a memorial in the church of St Swithun's.

Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. 

Links to the transcriptions are below.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

  • John Palmer, rector, 1662 (Will & Inventory)
  • Elias Winter, 1662 (Inventory)
  • John Peto/Petoe, 1670 (Inventory)
  • Anne Searle, widow, 1676 (Will)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Nately Scures Probate Material 1641-60
item.description:
Three inventories and one will survive for this period. They include a miller and a soap boiler.

Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. 

Links to the transcriptions are below.

 

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

  • Richard Aubery (Inventory), 1641
  • William Hall, senior, yeoman (Inventory), 1643
  • Hugh Loring, soap boiler (Will), 1656
  • John South (Inventory), 1660
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Nately Scures Probate Material 1621-40
item.description:
Seven wills and ten inventories survive for this period, reflecting the local farming community and the production of hops.

Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. 

Links to the transcriptions are below.

 

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

  • Nicholas Wilmott, wheelwright (Will and Inventory), 1623
  • John Garye, yeoman (Will and Inventory), 1624
  • Thomas Mannell, husbandman (Will and Inventory). 1629
  • Margery/Mardgery Cosens alias Byde , widow (Inventory), 1629
  • Robert Nash/Nashe, yeoman (Will and Inventory), 1630
  • Agnes Nash/Nashe, widow (Will and Inventory), 1634
  • William Draper, carpenter (Inventory), 1635
  • William Cocke, yeoman (Inventory), 1637
  • Richard Felsteed/Felstead, husbandman (Will and Inventory), 1638
  • John Welles, husbandman (Will and Inventory), 1639
  • Robert Melton, gentleman (Will and Inventory), 1640

item.title: Nately Scures Probate Material 1543-60
item.description:
The first four wills in this period reveal a traditional Catholic community who left their souls to the Virgin Mary and supported lights to burn in front of the statues of saints in the church. After 1560 the wills reflect the religion of the Reformation.

Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. 

Links to the transcriptions are below.

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

  • Anthony Read/Rede, 1543 (Will)
  • Edward Read/Rede, 1556 (Will and Inventory)
  • Edward Watlington/Watlyngton, carpenter, 1557 (Will and Inventory)
  • Thomas Hall, senior, 1558 (Will and Inventory)
  • John Hambly/Ambly, 1560 (Will and Inventory)
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Nately Scures Probate Material, 1543-1700
item.description:
The small parish of Nately Scures, lies on the A30 road four miles east of Basingstoke and two miles west from Hook. The majority of the parish is to the north of the road and stretches from the old turnpike at Water End. It also includes land owned by the Dorchester estate, Heather Row and Andwell. Until 1870 there were six detached parts of the parish including Holt and the then hamlet of Hook. The detached parts were attached to surrounding parishes in 1879.

Civil parish boundaries in the area were revised in 1932, consequent upon the creation of Hook Civil Parish. The remaining parts of Nately Scures were then transferred to Hook and Newnham and it ceased to exist as a civil parish. It finally ceased to be a separate unit of any kind in 1955, when the ecclesiastical parish was absorbed into the newly-created ecclesiastical parish of Hook.

Using probate documents from the Hampshire Record Office and National Archives, 34 wills and 44 inventories have been transcribed from 1543-1700 by the Wills Group of the Hampshire Victoria County History project based in Basingstoke. The documents reveal a mixed farming economy with associated rural crafts. It is noticeable that the testators of this parish situated on clay soil, have few sheep compared with neighbouring parishes on the chalk downland, but some do have hops, hop poles and apples. Words have been modernized and punctuation added to make reading easier but names have been transcribed as written. Words in italics indicate omissions in the original document which have been added to make sense of the text. Words in square brackets indicate that they have been transcribed as seen but where the meaning is unclear. 

A glossary is attached of unusual words.

  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1543-60
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1561-80
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1581-1600
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1601-20
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1621-40
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1641-60
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1661-80
  • Nately Scures Probate Material 1681-1700
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Nately Scures Census 1851-1901
item.description: Nately Scures was a small parish four miles north east of Basingstoke and adjoining Newnham. Until the late 19th century it had a core around the church and five detached areas. The boundaries were redrawn in the late 19th century when the detached parts became part of the surrounding parishes. In 1932 Nately Scures parish was abolished and its lands became part of Hook, Newnham and Odiham.
item.dc:creator: JeanM
